definition.value: A <process> in which a behaviour is followed by an event that alters the likelihood of occurrence of the behaviour.
If interested in more specific classes, see self-regulation and reinforcement learning
A <stimulus> that changes the likelihood of a preceding behaviour.
An <external stimulus> that causes memory retrieval.
A <mental disposition> to be self-efficacious despite experiences of failure.
A <stereotype> about people who are judged to be risk takers.
A <uniform process aggregate> whose members are reinforcement processes involving an individual over a period of time.
If interested in capturing timing, see the Schedule Ontology
A <social influence behaviour> where part of the school’s social environment exerts an influence on the behaviour of another.

label.value: self-efficacy belief for a behaviour during routine activities

definition.value: A <self-efficacy belief for a behaviour> that is enacted as part of activities that are routine.

label.value: self-efficacy belief for a behaviour in the face of social pressure

definition.value: A <situational self-efficacy belief for a behaviour> that is enacted against social pressire.

label.value: self-efficacy belief for a behaviour under conditions of stress

definition.value: A <situational self-efficacy belief for a behaviour> that is enacted when under stress.

label.value: self-efficacy belief for avoiding a threat

definition.value: A <self-efficacy belief> that one can take actions to avoid, reduce, or remove a threat or its effects.
A <goal> that a person has set for themselves.
A <behavioural motivation> that arises from a person’s self-identity.
A <self-regulation of behaviour> that is informed by feedback.
A <social identity> in which the representation is similarity between oneself and another person or group.

label.value: social embeddedness in a social group

definition.value: <Social embeddedness> that involves attachment to a social group.
An <environmental disposition> of the social environmental system.
An <attribute> of a social environmental system.
A <specifically dependent continuant> whose bearer is a social group.
A <mental process> that results from the person’s social identity.
An <interpersonal process> in which people’s thoughts, feelings or behaviours are influenced by other people.
If social influence processes are specific to behaviour, the entity “social influence behaviour” should be referred to.
A <social environmental disposition> that is how far members of a society experience fair and equitable resources, opportunities and privileges.

label.value: social reinforcement process for a behaviour

definition.value: A <reinforcement process> in which a behaviour is followed by a social event that alters the likelihood of the behaviour.
A <cognitive representation> about a behaviour that is shared by members of a social group.
This class includes the physical representation of the behaviour and also the meanings that members of a social group assign to it.
<Learning> about one’s social role.
A <personal value> that involves regarding societal wellbeing as fundamentally important in life.
An <environmental disposition> to have a stable and secure physical and social home environment.
An <entity> that acts as an input to a perceptual process leading to a thought, feeling or action.
A stimulus can be naturally occurring or used as component of Behaviour Change Techniques (BCTs). These are part of learning processes and operationalized as part of BCTs.
A <mental process> in which a stimulus strengthens a tendency for an impulse.
Stimulus-impulse association is part of operant learning processes.
A <mental process attribute> that is the extent to which attentional resources are focused on a target.
Target refers to anything that can be attended to, whether it be an object, an attribute of an object, information or a process.
A <social environmental disposition> that is the extend to which the social environemental system benefits the person’s thoughts, emotions or behaviours.
If you are interested in capturing a social environmental system that is supportive rather than to what extend a system is supportive, then please refer to "supportive social environmental system".
A <social environmental system> that benefits the person’s thoughts, emotions or behaviours.
If you are interested in capturing to what extend a system is supportive rather than the system itself, then please refer to "supportive social environmental disposition".
A <mental skill> to be able to process information in the form of symbols.
A <behavioural opportunity> that involves the extend to which technology is available in the environmental system.
A <mental disposition> to appraise imagined future occurrences differently according to how far in the future they are judged to occur.
A <data item> that is about belief about threat expressed as the likelihood of a potentially harmful occurrence weighted by the severity of the harm.
A <personal value> that involves regarding long-standing social customs as fundamentally important in life.
A <mental disposition> to behave in a way that seeks to maximise the net positive consequences of behaviour.
<Observational learning> through the feelings or actions of another person.
An <observational learning capability> through the feelings or actions of another person.
A <goal> that is specified in sufficient detail for it to be clear when the goal has been achieved.
A <bodily disposition> to adopt new behaviours.
This is a dimension that can be subdivided into very high, high, medium, low and very low.
An <emotional-relevance appraisal> of the extent to which something is good or beneficial.
<Learning> that occurs through observing the behaviour of others.
Participating in healthcare treatment in accordance with treatment instructions.
A goal-directed behaviour whose goal is to obtain the approval of another person.

label.value: association behaviour with a pro-social group

definition.value: An association behaviour that involves increasing a sense of being part of a pro-social group.
A process aggregate whose members are behaviours causally linked to each other in a sequence.
A behaviour chain can involve different behaviours, whereas a behaviour pattern can involve the same behaviour. Patterns are not necessarily causally linked.
An individual human behaviour pattern that is continued.
Behaviour is continued even if there are historical or current barriers to doing so.
An entity that is an outcome of behaviour.
